EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow combined with northwest winds of 25 to 40 mph to create blizzard conditions during the late evening and overnight hours on April 14th across Lincoln County.  Snowfall amounts of 6 to 14 inches fell across the northwestern two thirds of the county with snow drifts of 2 to 4 feet. By 10 p.m. CDT, Interstate 80 was shutdown further west at North Platte as the impacts from strong winds and deteriorating visibilities due to the combination of wind and snow led to numerous traffic accidents. The interstate opened at 3 p.m. on the 15th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense spring storm system tracked across western and north central Nebraska on April 14th and 15th, 2011.  As cold air was drawn into the system, light snow accumulations began in Sheridan county the morning of April 14th, with rain changing to snow in adjacent western counties by early afternoon.  By 3 pm CDT, western counties changed over to light and moderate snow, and after 5 pm, heavy snow began over much of the area west of a line from Cody in Cherry county through Hayes Center in Hayes county.  Visibilities, particularly near and east of highway 61 were a half mile or less and frequently a quarter mile or less through the evening hours.  These areas received the heaviest snowfall with 10 inches of snowfall common with as much as 16 inches at Paxton in eastern Keith county.  North winds of 30 to 45 mph developed across southwestern into west central Nebraska by late afternoon, creating blizzard conditions into the overnight hours.  Interstate 80 was closed for nearly 17 hours between North Platte and Sidney from about 9 pm Thursday until 245 pm Friday.  Dozens of motorists were stranded along the interstate, especially between Paxton and Ogallala within a construction zone.  Other motorists were reported stranded on highways 2 and 92 as well.  Snow drifts as high as 4 to 5 feet were reported.

A ridge of high pressure aloft moved north from the southern plains on July 16th and remained in place through July 20th.  Afternoon high temperatures during the period approached the mid and upper 90s to around 100 east of a line from Imperial, to North Platte to Valentine.  Though no record highs were set during this period, dew point temperatures in the 70s, resulted in heat indexes of 100 to 110 degrees during the late evening and afternoon hours from July 16th through July 20th.  Cooler and drier conditions arrived on the July 21st as the ridge of high pressure moved east into the mid and lower Mississippi valley.  No fatalities or injuries were reported as a result of the heat.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Planned releases from Kingsley Dam at Lake McConaughy (Keith County) were required to keep the elevation of the lake below a certain level going into the winter months.  These high releases kept the North Platte River at North Platte above major flood stage throughout the month.  The river stage stayed fairly steady through the entire month, varying from 6.7 feet to 6.9 feet. The maximum stage height was 6.9 feet which occurred on the 11th and the 12th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Elevated releases from Kingsley Dam at Lake McConaughy (Keith County) caused the North Platte River at North Platte to stay above flood stage for the entire month of August.  These high releases were needed to lower the elevation of the lake going into winter.  The lake had problems with high water due to deep snow pack in the Rocky Mountains from the 2010-2011 winter season combined with wet conditions during the spring and early summer months.  The river maintained a fairly steady flow at the North Platte site between 6.6 feet and 6.8 feet throughout August, which is above major flood stage.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The combination of high stream flows due to releases from Lake McConaughy and heavy rain upstream of North Platte caused the North Platte River to rise above flood stage.  The river remained above flood stage for one day, then after thunderstorms produced another two to four inches of rain just upstream of North Platte, the river once again briefly rose above flood stage.  The river crested at 6.08 feet at 6 p.m. CDT on the 13th, with minor flooding occurring.

A strong low pressure system produced widespread severe weather across the central plains on April 14th.  Storms developed over central Nebraska in the late morning hours which produced large hail over portions of Garfield and Wheeler counties. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Drought conditions (D2) expanded across western Nebraska toward the end of the month as rainfall deficits increased and above normal temperatures were experienced. The drought's effect on livestock and agricultural grew as the lack of moisture stunted the growth of dry land crops and pastures. The livestock, pasture and range report showed conditions rated 13 percent very poor, 30 poor and 0 excellent. The drought continued into July.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A drought, which began the in the middle of June expanded east into western Nebraska to impact hydrologic and agricultural types. Precipitation was well below normal as temperatures rose well above normal. The rainfall deficit increased where Broken Bow was -3.87 inches below normal and ranged to -1.84 inches below normal at Valentine which were both on the fringes of the designated D2 region, where 22 of the 26 counties were impacted. Dry land crops were hit the hardest where stunted growth of crops and pastures. The dry conditions led to wildfires ignited by lightning to include the most costly at Nebraska's Halsey Forest, where 1,043 acres was charred on June 30th. The drought expanded into July.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe drought conditions (D2), which began the month of June, intensified to extreme drought conditions (D3) by the end of the month. Pastures that make up close to 66 percent of the land use in Lincoln County (2007 Census USDA) that was rated 69% poor or very poor. The lack of rain limited grazing capacity as the departure from normal precipitation reached below 3 inches. Crop producers began silage of dryland corn. On July 23rd all counties in Nebraska were approved for CRP Emergency Haying and Grazing. The drought continued into August.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe drought conditions (D2) continued from late June into early July.  The combination of intense heat and a lack of rainfall, allowed extreme (D3) to expand to across all counties. Further, in eastern Custer County the prolong lack of rain resulted in exceptional (D4) drought conditions to develop by the end of the month.  Official observation platforms recorded their driest July period on record as rainfall deficits increased to below 2 to 3 inches in most areas north of Interstate 80. ||Nebraska's power grid took hits as well from the extremely hot temperatures and dry weather. The need for power was so great Custer Public Power District was forced into rolling blackouts for the Nebraska Sandhills on the 18th, when emergency relief was implemented as irrigation demands rose.  ||By the 23rd, the Nebraska Governor declared a state of emergency in all 93 Nebraska counties, and ordered the department of roads to allow roadside haying for the remainder of the summer.  ||Crop conditions across Nebraska deteriorated significantly by the end of the month.  According to the USDA, 37 percent of the total corn crop, 38 percent of the soybean crop and 83 percent of pastureland was rated either very poor or poor.  Irrigated corn rated 55 percent good to excellent, while dry land corn rated 5 percent good to excellent.  Many livestock producers have begun to haul water to cattle, while deteriorating pasture conditions have forced producers to sell their herds early.||The abnormally dry conditions led to numerous range fires started by lightning.  Two major fires occurred during the month.  One in Thomas County which burned approximately 1000 acres, and the Region 24 Wildfire that included Keya Paha, Brown, and Cherry counties, where approximately 76,000 acres burned.  ||Extreme (D3) and exceptional (D4) drought conditions continued into August.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The drought that began late June continued to into August and intensified from extreme (D3) to an exceptional (D4) drought for all except portions of the southeast. The weather pattern trended toward strong high pressure aloft that sustained dry and hot weather. Temperatures were above average and the suppressed rainfall led to spotty rainfall at best. The Drought Monitor continued to reflect short-term impacts, while the drought intensified into September.

Record low flows on streams have increased with an exception of the North Platte River below Kingsley Dam, where higher flows were maintained for irrigation needs. The fire dangers were elevated through the month. High based thunderstorms brought an increase risk of fire starts. The drought continued into September.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The drought began in June and continued to intensify through September as below normal precipitation was observed across Lincoln County. For the month, rainfall was up to 2 inches below normal, while the yearly precipitation deficit was in excess of 8 inches for most locations. By the end of September, all of Lincoln County saw conditions worsen from Extreme (D3) to Exceptional (D4) drought.  These conditions continued into October.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The drought, which began in June, continued to intensify through September as another month of below normal precipitation was observed across western and north central Nebraska. A few significant storm systems did move across the central plains during the month, but produced very little rainfall across the area.  The drought caused a large fluctuations in temperatures with high temperatures being above normal, while low temperatures dropped to below normal values much of the month.  By the end of September, the Drought Monitor had expanded the area under Exceptional Drought (D4) across all of western and north central Nebraska as most places were experiencing a precipitation deficit in excess of eight inches for the year.  Affects of the drought included below normal to near record low flows on many of the rivers and streams across the area, damaged crops and pastures, lowered ground water levels leading to shallow wells drying up, as well as extreme fire danger.  In addition, the drought increased irrigation needs, which led to higher flows along the North Platte River which quickly depleted the water storage at Lake McConaughy.  The abundant dry air caused thunderstorms to produce little or no rainfall, which increased the threat for lightning strike fires.  Many grass fires were observed across the area, and while most were small, several larger fires occurred, requiring higher amounts of resources.  The drought continued into October.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The drought that began in June continued through November, where an exceptional Drought (D4) conditions remain. A break in the heat did occur as several arctic cold fronts pushed south for some precipitation. Yet, rainfall remains below normal and temperatures above normal. The drought continued into December.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The drought persisted into November with Exceptional Drought (D4) condition. In November rainfall remained below normal and the average daily mean temperatures  above normal for little change in soil conditions. The USDA reported in Nebraska 97 percent of pasture and range land with Poor to Very Poor conditions, while winter wheat in Nebraska was assessed 46 percent in the Poor to Very Poor as of November 25th. The media's focus has turned to the winter wheat with dim outlooks given to farmers facing a forecast of drought persistence on the U.S. Drought Monitor.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The drought that began in June continued through December, where exceptional Drought (D4) conditions remain. There were several storm systems that brought precipitation mainly in the form of snow for the month, although the HPRCC reported Lincoln County received between 50 to 125 percent of the normal precipitation for the month. The drought continued into January 2013.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The drought persisted into December with Exceptional Drought (D4) condition. In December rainfall was below normal and the average daily mean temperatures were 1 to 5 degrees above normal. The USDA reported that 49 percent of Nebraskas Wheat crop was in Poor to Very Poor condition for the month of December.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winter storm conditions indirectly contributed to the fatality of a male driver on Interstate 80 near North Platte when the vehicle slid into the rear of a semi-truck around 1230 p.m. on December 19, 2012.  The accident forced the closure of Interstate 80 for a few hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense winter storm tracked from southeastern Colorado into Nebraska. The winter storm brought winter storm and blizzard conditions to portions of the southeast panhandle into southwest and central Nebraska on December 19, 2012.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: North Platte ASOS recorded strong north winds of 30 to 40 mph with occasional gusts to near 50 mph during the afternoon hours. These strong winds created blizzard conditions with visibility below a quarter mile for at least 3 hours along with considerable blowing and drifting snow. The blizzard conditions caused the closure of Interstate 80. Total snowfall across Lincoln County ranged from 3 to 7 inches.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense winter storm tracked from southeastern Colorado into Nebraska. The winter storm brought winter storm and blizzard conditions to portions of the southeast panhandle into southwest and central Nebraska on December 19, 2012.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The drought that began in June 2012 continued into January 2013. The exceptional (D4) drought lingered as below normal precipitation fell during the month.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The drought that began in June and expanded to become an Exceptional (D4) Drought in 2012 continues into January 2013. While the weather in January was characterized as progressive the storm track provided little relief or recharge to the depleted soil moisture. Short term impacts are expected to hit agriculture and grasslands, while the long-term impacts to hydrological and ecological interests are expected to linger. In January some rainfall did occur although departures remain over four inches that keep fire dangers and potential impacts at the forefront and in the news.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Nebraska State Patrol notified WFO North Platte of a plane that took off from the North Platte Regional Airport, Lee Bird Field (LBF) at 1546 CST and lost contact seven minutes later at 1553 CST. At the time weather conditions at LBF included freezing drizzle and visibility of three miles, with a cloud ceiling of 900 feet. The plane was a multi-engine BE-58 manufactured by Raytheon according to a FAA spokeswoman. The plane crashed 11 miles northeast of North Platte in the Maxwell area. Four male fatalities (indirect) occurred in the crash.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: January 11, 2013 a powerful upper level low pressure system moved through the Plains and brought winter weather conditions to western and north central Nebraska. Snow and blowing snow was forecasted for the eastern Panhandle and the western Sandhills of Nebraska. Further southeast, to include Lee Bird Field (LBF) in Lincoln County, areas of patchy freezing drizzle or light freezing would give way to snow before the threat for freezing precipitation would end around midnight. A plane that took off from the North Platte Regional Airport at 1553 CST crashed about 11 miles northeast of the airport, in the Maxwell area. The aircraft crashed resulting in four fatalities (indirect).

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The drought that began in June 2012 continued through February 2013. The exceptional (D4) drought lingered despite slightly above normal precipitation during the month.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The drought that began in June 2012 and expanded to become an Exceptional (D4) Drought in October 2012 continues into February 2013. While the weather in February became more active, with two major snowfall events, only minor relief or recharge to the depleted soil moisture occurred. Long-term impacts to hydrological and ecological interests are expected to linger. In February, areas of significant snowfall did occur with monthly precipitations departures ranging from around a half inch above normal at North Platte and Valentine to near normal at Broken Bow and Imperial.  This helped to keep fire dangers and long term impacts from worsening.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snowfall amounts of 8 inches occurred across Lincoln County beginning during the early evening hours on February 20th through the evening hours on February 21st.  Northeast winds up to 15 to 25 mph also created areas of blowing snow.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system moved out of the southern Rockies bringing a prolonged period of snow to western and north central Nebraska beginning during the early evening on February 20th through the overnight hours on February 21st. Snowfall totals ranged from around eight inches across portions of west central Nebraska into eastern portions of north central Nebraska to near 12 inches in Hayes and Frontier county in southwest Nebraska.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The drought that began in June 2012 lingered with Exceptional Drought (D4) conditions. Observed precipitation ranged a half inch to localized 1.5 inches in central Lincoln County. The average precipitation was below the normal 1.5 inches. The precipitation helped the parched ground, yet insufficient to reduce the overall impact of the ongoing drought. The drought continued into April.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The drought that began in June 2012 lingered with Exceptional Drought (D4) conditions continuing into March. There was some localized improvements in portions of Sheridan, Cherry and Deuel counties as sufficient moisture resulted in a downgrade to Extreme Drought (D3) conditions by the end of the month. A combination of rain and snowfall during the month provided some relief, however the a large percentage of the area received less than 75 percent of the normal precipitation of 1.5 to 2 inches in March.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Precipitation in April helped ease the Exceptional (D4) drought conditions that began in June of 2012.  The county received a range of precipitation from a half inch in the west to localized areas of 3 inches in the east central and northeast. The higher rainfall amounts in the east helped improve the soil moisture with Extreme (D3) conditions by the end of the month. The drought continued into May.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Precipitation did arrive in April in the form of a mixture of rain, snow and thunderstorms. The north central received the higher totals, where up to 5 inches was recorded during the month. The drought that began in June 2012 has lingered for 10 months and Exceptional (D4) conditions since October. By April 30th twelve counties retained D4 conditions with McPherson County receiving the least rainfall and no change to drought severity. The drought continued into May.

A warm front lifted north across southwest Nebraska and was the focus for thunderstorms to develop, intensify and produce large hail and damaging winds. Frontier County was hit the hardest by damaging winds estimated up to 80 mph as a thunderstorm bowed out. The high winds produced damage at 12 farmsteads. The most extensive damage occurred just north of County Road 741, where two large buildings and nine silos were destroyed. The wind damage included over 60 center pivot irrigation systems, livestock killed, large tree limbs down and approximately 40 power poles snapped. The McCook Public Power District reported 173 consumers lost power during the storm.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The drought that began in June 2012 lingered into May. Convective rainfall produced  rainfall amounts from 3 to 10 inches with the higher amounts in the east. The rain was beneficial that helped lower the drought impacts with a range from Severe (D2) Drought conditions in the east to Exceptional (D4) Drought conditions in the northwest by the end of the month. The drought lingered into June.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The drought that began in June of 2012 lingered in May, although thunderstorms produced some significant rainfall to further ease the ongoing drought. All areas received a minimum of two inches of rainfall and some over eight inches. The areal coverage of the Exceptional Drought (D4) conditions in western Nebraska was reduced to focus over the south central sandhills, while a larger portion of northern and north central Nebraska were lowered into the category of Severe Drought.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The drought that began in June 2012 persisted into August 2013. Thunderstorms provided rainfall in the amount of 1.75 to 3.50 inches across the county, which was enough to ease mainly Extreme Drought (D3) to a mix of Extreme Drought (D3) and Severe Drought across of the county. The drought persisted into September.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The drought that began in June 2012 persisted through August 2013. Exceptional (D4) and Extreme (D3) conditions covered nearly 30 percent of the state. The Exceptional Drought (D4) conditions had improved to Extreme drought (D3) conditions in the Central Sandhills. However, most of the Extreme Drought (D3) conditions existed in western Nebraska.

Severe thunderstorms developed on Thursday afternoon along a warm front across  northern Nebraska. Numerous reports of large hail were noted, with the largest up to the size of baseballs.  Damaging winds, funnel clouds and heavy rainfall were also reported during this severe weather event. The preliminary local storm damage survey information, estimated the highest winds speeds in North Platte were near 100 miles an hour - where numerous large trees and large limbs were downed.  This also led to some power outages and damage to vehicles and homes. Large hail caused broken windows, from north of Whitman to southeast of the Bartlett area.  No tornadoes were confirmed, although funnel clouds were reported with supercell thunderstorms near Mullen, Arnold, and in southwestern Custer County. Extensive crop damage was found in southwestern Custer County where acres of corn and bean crops were damaged or destroyed from hail estimated up to the size of golfballs.

At the end of September, the northern half of the county and much of the southeast quarter of the county were in Severe Drought (D2), while the southwest quarter along with other portions of far southern Lincoln County remain in Extreme Drought (D3). The drought persisted into October.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The drought that began in June 2012 persisted through September 2013.  Conditions did improve through the month as western and north central Nebraska received normal to above normal precipitation.  Although drought conditions improved, Extreme drought (D3) conditions remained from the Western Sandhills into southwest Nebraska at the end of the month, while the rest of western and north central Nebraska continued to be in Moderate (D1) to Severe (D2) drought.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding occurred along the South Platte River from September 20th through September 26th as water from the historic rains in Colorado moved through the river system. Cropland and pastureland along the river was flooded. In North Platte, several homes had minor damage and 14 roads were closed as storm drains backed up in parts of the city. Southeast of North Platte, at least two roads were closed, with one business and an unknown number of outbuildings being flooded near and east of Nebraska Link 56G.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Historical rains fell across the front range of the Colorado Rocky Mountains September 9th-15th.  These rains, which totaled over the yearly average across this area which totaled up to 17 inches in places fell largely within the South Platte River basin.  As the water was routed downstream along the South Platte River in western Nebraska and then into the Platte River in central Nebraska record flooding was observed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The drought that began in June 2012 continued through January 2014 across much of western Nebraska. Precipitation was sparse during the month that led to continued Severe Drought (D2) conditions with Extreme Drought (D3) conditions in parts of six counties, the most extensive in Chase County. Precipitation ranged from less than a half-inch across the north to local areas up to one inch in the southwest in the form of snowfall.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: North Platte ASOS recorded sustained winds of 40 to 45 mph with gusts up to 60 mph from late morning through mid afternoon. Winds of this magnitude occurred across Lincoln County.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense upper level system and deep surface low pressure tracked across the region January 16, 2014. Very strong northwest winds sustained at 35 to 50 mph with gusts near 65 mph occurred. This also caused areas of blowing dust with the lowest visibility near zero in Frontier county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The drought that began in June 2012 continued through February 2014. Extreme (D3) drought continued into March across the southwestern quarter of Lincoln County, while severe (D2) drought continue across the remainder of Lincoln County.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Normal to above normal precipitation fell across the central and western Sandhills as well as southwestern Nebraska during the month of February.  Total precipitation ranged from a half an inch in southwestern Nebraska, to around an inch in the central Sandhills.  In light of the normal to above normal precipitation, several counties remained in severe (D2) to extreme (D3) drought conditions over the central and western Sandhills...as well as southwestern Nebraska.  The area of severe (D2) to extreme (D3) drought remained unchanged during the month of February.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The drought that began in June 2012 lingered. Extreme (D3) drought conditions continued across the southwestern quarter of Lincoln County with Severe (D2) drought conditions over the remainder. The drought continued into April.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In March significant snow fell in narrow bands that led to below normal precipitations for portions of the northern sandhills, southwest and up to 2 inches below normal for areas east of a line from Spencer to Merna. The areas of below normal precipitation led to continued Severe (D2) to Extreme (D3) Drought conditions in the west, yet also caused an expansion of drought conditions into portions of north central Nebraska to include portions of Blaine, Loup, Garfield, and Custer counties as Moderate (D1) conditions worsened into Severe (D2) drought conditions.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The drought that began in June 2012 lingered. Extreme (D3) drought conditions continued across the southwestern half of Lincoln County with Severe (D2) drought conditions over the remainder of the county. These drought conditions continued into May.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: From southwest Nebraska into eastern portions of north central Nebraska, much below normal precipitation ranging from a inch to locally more than two inches occurred for the month of April. The area of Severe (D2) to Extreme (D3) Drought conditions remained the same across much of southwest Nebraska into the central Sandhills to end the month of April.

The strong winds were reported to have destroyed a grain bin in Hershey.

Severe thunderstorms developed on June 3rd, during the early morning hours in north central Nebraska, and produced some large hail. During the late morning and early afternoon hours, severe thunderstorms developed and moved into eastern portion of north central Nebraska. Significant wind damage occurred in portions of Rock and western Holt County destroying some grain bins, overturning center pivots and causing downed power lines. Thunderstorms re-intensified by mid afternoon north of a warm front draped west to east across western and north central Nebraska. Numerous reports of large hail and damaging winds occurred, which lasted through mid evening.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The official NWS observation reported 11.4 inches of snowfall. Public reports of 10 to 12 inches were common across Lincoln County. As northerly winds increased to 30 to 40 mph during the overnight and morning hours on February 2nd, low visibility with 3 to 4 foot drifts occurred. Interstate 80 and Highway 30 were closed on February 2nd and did not reopen until February 3rd.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong winter storm moved across the region on February 1st and 2nd and produced heavy snowfall amounts of 8 to 15 inches across portions of western and north central Nebraska.  Strong northerly winds of 30 to 40 mph with occasional gusts to 50 mph caused considerable blowing and drifting snow with blizzard or near blizzard conditions. Interstate 80 and many other roads were closed on February 2nd and did not reopen until February 3rd.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong west winds of 30 to 40 mph with a few gusts to near 60 mph occurred across Lincoln county during the late evening hours on February 18th and the early morning hours on February 19th. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong Pacific cold front moved quickly across portions of western and north central Nebraska during the late evening and overnight hours on February 18th-19th. West winds of 30 to 40 mph with occasional gusts to around 60 mph occurred at some locations.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong north winds of 35 to 45 mph with gusts to around 50 mph developed in the afternoon.  These strong winds combined with moderate intensity snowfall to create near blizzard conditions.  Visibility was reduced to below a quarter mile at times from the afternoon until the early evening hours.  Snowfall amounts ranged from 3 to 6 inches across Lincoln County.  The snow and low visibility resulted in the closure of Interstate 80 and U.S. highway 30 in the afternoon and evening until the snow and blowing snow had ended.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong winter storm moved across the region on March 23rd and produced heavy snowfall amounts of 2 to 10 inches across portions of western and north central Nebraska. Strong northerly winds of 30 to 40 mph with occasional gusts to 50 mph caused considerable blowing and drifting snow with near blizzard conditions. Interstate 80, highway 30 and some other roads were closed from the late afternoon on March 23rd, and did not reopen until after the snow ended early on March 24th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong north winds of 35 to 45 mph with gusts to around 50 mph developed by mid afternoon.  These strong winds combined with moderate intensity snowfall to create near blizzard conditions.  Visibility was reduced to below a quarter mile at times from the late afternoon through the mid evening hours.  Snowfall amounts were heaviest across the northwest half of Lincoln county, ranging from 4 to 8 inches, while the southwest half of the county ranged from 1 to 3 inches.  The snow and low visibility resulted in the closure of Interstate 80 and U.S. highway 30 by late afternoon until after midnight, when the snow and blowing snow had ended.

Strong northerly winds of 30 to 40 mph with occasional gusts to 50 mph caused considerable blowing and drifting snow with near blizzard conditions. Interstate 80, highway 30 and some other roads were closed from the late afternoon on March 23rd, and did not reopen until after the snow ended early on March 24th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor to moderate flooding began on May 15th along the North Platte River above and below Lake McConaughy.  Flooding was due to excessive runoff in the North Platte River Basin in Wyoming. This coupled with seasonal snow melt, led to high flows along the North Platte River upstream of Lake McConaughy. As the reservoir neared capacity, additional water was released from the lake, resulting in minor to moderate flooding along the North Platte River downstream of Lake McConaughy.  River levels crested at 4.4 feet, 8.9 feet and 6.9 feet at Lisco, Lewellen and North Platte respectively.  The crest was 0.4 feet above the flood stage at Lisco, 1.4 feet above the flood stage at Lewellen and 0.9 feet above the flood stage at North Platte.  One home was evacuated along North River road in North Platte due to the moderate flooding. ||Along the Platte river in eastern Lincoln county, the river reached flood stage on May 23rd and crested on May 31st.  The crest at Brady was 7.8 feet on the 31st, which was 0.3 feet above the flood stage of 7.5 feet.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy spring rain, coupled with snow melt from the Rockies, led to high river flows along the South Platte, North Platte, and main stem Platte rivers during the second half of May. Minor to moderate flooding occurred at Lisco, Lewellen and North Platte along the North Platte river, while minor flooding occurred near Brady along the main stem Platte River.
